children.text: Standard 1 Students understand the significance of theatre and its relationship to history and cultures.
Identify elements of theatre in everyday life, such as relationships (characters), clothes (costumes), locations (setting).
Recognize and discuss theatre as an expression and record of the human experience told through stories, songs, and dances.
Identify the many types of live presentations (film, television, and electronic technology) through history and culture.
Identify elements of theatre in everyday life, such as relationships (characters), clothes (costumes), locations (setting).
Recognize and discuss theatre as an expression and record of the human experience told through stories, songs, and dances.
List qualities of various types of live presentations (film, television, and electronic technology).
Identify elements of theatre in everyday life, such as relationships (characters), clothes (costumes), locations (setting).
Explore theatre as a reflection of the culture and history of communities.
Compare and contrast the differences between live and recorded performances.
Explore the ways people in the past have used performance or ritual to communicate.
Examine the dynamic relationship between community, culture, and the theatre.
Examine the value of theatre as a means of integrating history and culture.
Explore the unique way theatre can be used to understand the history of Indiana and its people.
Trace the development of theatre in Indiana.
Examine the value of theatre as a means of integrating history and culture.
Explore the connection between theatre history of North America and its people.
Identify various theatrical practices throughout North American history.
Examine the value of theatre as a means of integrating history and culture.
Explore how the roots of theatre began in ancient Greece and flourished through other eras and regions.
Identify the ways in which many cultures have used theatre to communicate ideas.
Explore the impact of culture and tradition on Asian and African theatre.
Describe and compare universal characters and situations in dramas from various cultures and periods.
Analyze theatre's depiction of early American history.
Explain and demonstrate how culture affects theatre performances and styles.
PROFICIENT: Discover how our individual cultural experiences affect an artist's work in the theatre.
ADVANCED: Analyze the ways our individual cultural experiences impact our work in the theatre.
PROFICIENT: Compare how similar dramatic themes are treated from various cultures and periods.
ADVANCED: Create informal performances which reveal universal, crosscultural issues and themes.
Standard 2 Students recognize significant works of the theatre and comprehend various performance styles.
Recognize and discuss cultural traditions in stories, songs, fairy tales, fables, and nursery rhymes.
Recognize and discuss cultural traditions in stories, songs, fairy tales, fables, and nursery rhymes.
Explore the different ways stories can be told.
Recognize the differences between literary forms such as prose or scripted plays.
Identify the various ways that a story could be performed.
Discover the ways that Indiana heritage is preserved theatrically.
Explore the works of Indiana writers and playwrights.
View examples of Indiana history and culture in performance.
Examine dramatic genres (comedy, tragedy, melodrama, and farce).
Observe a performance of musical theatre and discuss its American heritage.
Identify historical periods and their theatrical styles.
Distinguish among differences between western and non-western theatre.
Read excerpts from two non-Western plays and discuss their cultural contexts.
Delineate the differences between melodramatic and realistic acting styles.
Compare and cont rast the dramatic style and form of melodramatic and realistic American plays.
PROFICIENT: Identify various dramatic forms, production practices, and theatrical traditions.
ADVANCED: Adapt various dramatic forms, production practices, and theatrical traditions across cultures and historical periods to contemporary theatre.
Standard 3 Students understand and analyze the dramatic structure of plays and performances.
Identify and describe the character, plot, and setting in stories.
Identify and describe the character, plot, and setting in classroom dramatizations and/or formal productions.
Identify and describe the character, plot, and setting in stories.
Identify and describe the character, plot, and setting in classroom dramatizations and/or formal productions.
Identify and describe the character, plot, and setting in stories.
Identify and describe the character, plot, and setting in classroom dramatizations and/or formal productions.
Explore the use of sounds and the voice to express character, feelings, and mood.
Create spontaneous dialogue to express feelings.
Identify and describe character, plot, theme, and setting in stories.
Identify and describe the character, plot, and setting in classroom dramatizations and/or formal productions.
Discuss and classify character, plot, theme, and setting in stories.
Identify and describe the character, plot, and setting in classroom dramatizations and/or formal productions.
Classify and explain character, plot, theme, and setting in various stories.
Explain the use of character, plot, and setting in classroom dramatizations and/or formal productions.
Explore thematic and character elements of a play.
Scrutinize a character's actions and the consequences they create.
Examine how the plot and dialogue of a play contribute to its overall impact.
PROFICIENT: Articulate understanding of a play us ing elements of dramatic structure (plot, character, theme, language, music, and spectacle).
ADVANCED: Differentiate dramatic works in terms of their form and style, such as Greek Tragedy, French Neoclassical, Theatre of the Absurd, and others.
PROFICIENT: Analyze the central action of the play and discuss its cause and effect.
ADVANCED: Analyze the way in which the theme or meaning of a play represents a view or comment on life, using textual evidence to support the claim.
Standard 4 Students identify, develop and apply criteria to make informed judgments about theatre.
Make use of age-appropriate theatre vocabulary to critique what they see, hear, and understand.
Speculate on the meaning of a performance.
Make use of age-appropriate theatre vocabulary to critique what they see, hear, and understand.
Speculate on the meaning of a performance.
Use age-appropriate theatre vocabulary to critique what they see, hear, and understand.
Speculate on the meaning of a performance of a play or story.
Use selected criteria to critique what they see, hear, and understand.
Speculate on the meaning of a performance.
Develop selected criteria to critique what they see, hear, and understand.
Speculate on the meaning of a performance.
Articulate what changes they would suggest in a performance.
Develop selected criteria to critique what they see, hear, and understand.
Speculate on the meaning of a performance.
Articulate what they would do differently in a performance.
Develop criteria to critique what they see, hear, and understand.
Speculate on the meaning of a theatrical production.
Use age-appropriate theatre vocabulary to critique and evaluate the effectiveness of theatrical productions.
Reflect on the quality of self and peer performances.
Use age-appropriate theatre vocabulary to develop a rubric for critiquing and evaluating the effectiveness of theatrical productions.
Differentiate the strengths and weaknesses of self and peer performances.
PROFICIENT: Evaluate how well the text or production met its intended objectives.
ADVANCED: Evaluate how well the text or production succeeded based on a developed set of personal aesthetic criteria.
PROFICIENT: Evaluate the artistic choices of self and the collaborative efforts of peers in classroom dramatizations and formal productions and suggest constructive alternatives.
ADVANCED: Analyze and evaluate critical comments about personal dramatic work explaining which points are most appropriate to realize further development of the work.
Standard 5 Students reflect on and interpret the nature of the theatre experience and its personal and artistic significance.
Respond to plays, stories, songs, fairy tales, fables, and nursery rhymes.
Respond to plays, stories, songs, fairy tales, fables, and nursery rhymes.
Respond to stories and plays. What did you think? How did you feel? Should we go see more plays like this one?
Recognize and respond to the unique qualities of the theatre experience.
Recognize and respond to the unique qualities of the theatre experience.
Recognize and respond to the unique qualities of the theatre experience.
Reflect on the qualities of the visual and aural production and how they create the viewer's reaction to the theatre experience.
Compare the character's conflict or problems to the real life concerns of the audience.
Understand the meaning of a theatrical production and evaluate its importance to the world and to themselves.
Compare the character's conflict or problems to the real life concerns of the audience.
Understand the use of technical elements of a production and evaluate their effect on the meaning of a production.
Apply a play's conflict or problems to the political and social concerns of the contemporary world.

PROFICIENT: Construct social meanings from classroom dramatizations and formal productions from a variety of cultures and historical periods and relate these to current personal, national, and international issues.
ADVANCED: Support emotional and intellectual responses to a variety of classroom, traditional, and non-traditional performances and articulate an individual point of view.
Standard 6 Students create scripts and theatre pieces through collaboration, inquiry and improvisation.
Dramatize stories by pretending (improvisation).
Create and present original stories.
Explore the use of sound effects and the voice to express character, feelings, and mood.
Dramatize stories using improvisation and theatre games.
Collaborate to create and present original stories.
Explore the use of sound effects and the voice to express character, feelings, and mood.
Dramatize short stories using improvisation and theatre games.
Collaboratively improvise scenes based on personal experiences.
Dramatize stories using improvisation and theatre games.
Collaboratively improvise scenes based on personal experiences.
Explore the use of sounds and the voice to express character, feelings, and mood.
Create spontaneous dialogue to express feelings.
Create a short dramatic scene from narrative literature.
Collaboratively improvise scenes based on relationships and social situations.
Investigate and create characters and plots from a variety of resources.
Explore the use of sounds and the voice to express character, feelings, and mood.
Create spontaneous dialogue to express feelings.
Adapt prose into a short play.
Investigate and create characters and plots from a variety of resources.
Explore the use of sounds and the voice to express character, feelings, and mood.
Create spontaneous dialogue to express feelings.
Improvise scenes from literature.
Write a scripted play based on a theme.
Explore the use of sounds and the voice to express character, feelings, and mood.
Generate dialogue for a simple scene using improvisation.
Use fictional or non-fictional resources to create a short script.
Generate dialogue for a short scene using improvisation.
Use fictional or non-fictional sources to create a short script.
PROFICIENT: Construct imaginative scripts and collaborate with actors to refine scripts so that the story and meaning are conveyed to an audience.
ADVANCED: Synthesizing research of a given period or historical event, create an original monologue or script that includes original characters with unique dialogue that motivates action.
Standard 7 Students utilize imagination and research to design and implement the elements of a visual environment.
Use classroom materials to create visual environments for creative play.
Use family, school, and community resources to gather information about the appearance of a specific environment.
Use classroom materials to create visual environments for creative play.
Use family, school, and community resources to gather information about the appearance of a specific environment.
Conceive and draw an imagined visual environment.
Arrange the classroom furniture to reflect the layout of a real place.
Conceive and draw or write a description of an imagined visual environment.
Arrange the classroom furniture to reflect the layout of a real place.
Conceive, draw, and build a simple imagined environment.
Apply research to the process of developing a simple, dramatic environment.
Study a play or story and then visualize, draw, and build a realistic theatrical environment.
Study a play or story and visualize, draw, and build a simple realistic theatrical environment for it.
Draw, write a description, or find images to convey a specific play's setting and mood.
Study a play or story, and visualize, draw, and create a simple theatrical environment for it.
Draw or find images appropriate to a specific play's setting and mood.
Based on research of a play or story, visualize, draw, and create an environment for the stage.
PROFICIENT: Respond to an existing play and translate that response into viable design elements (lights, sound, set, costume, makeup).
ADVANCED: Formulate a design concept from an existing play that reflects an apt interpretation of its text, style, and atmosphere.
Standard 8 Students develop acting skills through observation, improvisation and script analysis.
Observe and discuss the appearance and characteristics of people, creatures, and things.
Imitate or create people, creatures, or things based on observation.
Discuss stories to understand character relationships.
Observe and discuss the appearance and characteristics of people, creatures, and things.
Imitate or create people, creatures, or things based on observation.
Discuss stories to understand and describe character relationships.
Based on an observation of a person or animal, write a "behavior outline" describing specific movements and characteristics.
Through physical actions, depict a human or animal character.
Read a short play and discuss the relationships and behaviors of its characters.
Based on an observation of a person or animal, create a character profile describing specific movements and characteristics.
Through physical actions, depict a human or animal character.
Read a play and discuss the relationships and behaviors of its characters.
Observe skilled actors.
Create and present an age-appropriate character in a real- life situation.
Read plays to examine character dynamics and relationships.
Interact with skilled actors.
Create and present an age-appropriate character in a real- life situation.
Read plays to examine character dynamics and relationships.
Interact with a skilled actor in a collaborative exercise.
Write and perform dialogue for characters from familiar stories.
Demonstrate basic stage movement.
Observe human behavior and depict it through improvisation.
Read plays to understand character relationships.
Discover the physical tools used for acting.
Observe and depict human behavior through group improvisation.
Read plays to understand character development, motivation, and relationships.
PROFICIENT: Recognize and develop the voice and body as the actor's primary instruments.
ADVANCED: Convey character through specific physical and vocal choices.
PROFICIENT: Analyze a script to discover the clues about inner life of a character.
ADVANCED: Employ a careful process of script analysis in the creation of a character.
PROFICIENT: Utilize observation as a tool in the process of creating a character.
ADVANCED: Create a character by combining, modifying, or adapting various observations.
PROFICIENT: Build characters and portray situations through improvisation.
ADVANCED: Improvise a sustainable, original scene with believable characters in recognizable situations.
Standard 9 Students recognize a variety of theatrical careers.
Discover what actors do and find examples in the local community, film, or television.
Identify the various jobs people do in the theatre, such as actor, usher, box office attendant, stagehand, and carpenter.
Identify the various jobs people do behind the scenes, such as light board operator, sound board operator, stage manager, and stage hands.
Discover what designers, directors, and playwrights do in the theatre.
Identify various opportunities in theatre-related careers both on and offstage.
Discover the skills needed to be an actor.
Identify a wide variety of professions that use the talents and training of actors, such as voice-overs, commercials, amusement park entertainment, and public relations.
Discover the skills needed to be a playwright.
Identify a wide variety of professions related to playwriting, such as novelist, critic, journalist, promoter, poet, and screenwriter.
Discover the skills needed to be a theatrical designer.
Identify a wide variety of professions related to theatrical design, such as fashion designer, interior decorator, make- up artist, architect, engineer, and electrician.
Discover the skills needed to be a director.
Identify a wide variety of professions related to directing such as, television or film director, stage manager, producer, and artistic director.
PROFICIENT: Identify connections between theatre arts education and potential job opportunities in the community.
ADVANCED: Document and create a theatre arts career plan based on a portfolio and investigation of educational possibilities.
PROFICIENT: Identify criteria for admission into various theatre-related professions.
ADVANCED: Develop a plan for employment or further education through audition, interview, or presentation of a portfolio.
Standard 10 Students develop a lifelong commitment to theatre arts and value their importance in the life of the community.
Experience live theatre.
Experience live theatre.
Discuss what makes theatre a unique activity.
Experience live theatre.
Identify local theatre activities and how they add to the life of the community.
Experience live theatre.
Discuss how theatre adds to community life.
Take a backstage tour of a theatre.
Analyze the theatrical nature of familiar Indiana cultural events.
Observe a rehearsal or other behind-the-scenes activity of a local, professional, community, or high school play.
Volunteer to assist a theatre company (post flyers or posters, stuff envelopes, locate props).
Become familiar with a play and see a local production of it.
Attend a play or musical and write a critique analyzing the audience's response to the production.
PROFICIENT: Attend and critique theatrical productions and analyze the effects of these experiences.
ADVANCED: Attend and critique theatrical productions and analyze the effects of these experiences on one's individual growth and critical aesthetic.
PROFICIENT: Recognize the responsibilities and the importance of individual theatre patrons in the community.
ADVANCED: Identify service opportunities for supporting theatre in the community and become actively involved.
Standard 11 Students identify and make connections between theatre and other disciplines, such as language arts, social studies, humanities, science, and technology.
Use a dramatization to understand a concept from another discipline.
Use a theatre technique to understand a concept from another discipline.
Create a theatre piece that helps explain a relationship.
Create a theatre piece that integrates principles and ideals of American society.
Create a theatre piece exploring human relationships.
Identify and compare similar concepts or principles found in theatre and another discipline.
Create a theatre piece that explores a social issue.
Identify and compare similar concepts or principles found in theatre and another discipline, such as mathematics.
Create a theatre piece that states and supports a position.
Identify and compare similar concepts or principles found in theatre and another discipline, such as civics and government.
Create a theatre piece that explores a controversial issue.
Identify the ways theatre encourages cooperation in seeking solutions to mutual problems.
Trace advancements in technology and their impact on the theatre.
Analyze the ways theatre responds to social changes and cycles.
PROFICIENT: Compare characteristics of theatre within a particular historical period or style with similar ideas, issues, or themes in other disciplines.
ADVANCED: Associate the creative and analytical principles and techniques of theatre with other disciplines.
PROFICIENT: Create works (scenes, debates, critiques, or journals) that demonstrate knowledge of other disciplines through theatre activities.
ADVANCED: Integrate disciplines to create works (scenes, debates, critiques, or journals) that persuasively communicate in-depth knowledge and understanding of a concept.
Standard 12 Students understand the integrative nature of theatre that includes dance, music, visual art, and media arts.
Find other art forms used in theatre pieces.
Describe the ways other art forms enhance a theatre piece.
Use another art form to create a theatre piece.
Incorporate two other art forms into the creation of a theatre piece.
Analyze the ways a live performance is enhanced by the integration of other art forms.
Create a theatre piece by utilizing students' collaborative talents in each of the various arts.
Incorporate multiple art forms to more effectively communicate ideas.
Utilize recorded or live theatre performances to analyze the integrated use of the arts.
Summarize and critique the integrated use of the arts in recorded or live theatre performances.
PROFICIENT: Compare the materials, technologies, media, and processes of theatre with those of dance, music, or visual arts.
ADVANCED: Synthesize the creative and analytical principles, themes, and techniques of theatre and other art forms.
PROFICIENT: Create works that integrate media, processes, and concepts of other art forms.
ADVANCED: Create works that integrate media, processes, and concepts of other art forms to persuasively convey comprehensive knowledge gained through integration.
